Before coming to Congress, I worked at the United Nations and the State Department. I‚Äôd worked on post-coup transitions and responses to violent extremism and electoral violence in places around the world. I‚Äôd been in scary situations before.
I never thought the most dangerous place I could be was the United States Capitol. But on January 6, the United States Capitol became a conflict setting.

Fashioning weapons out of stanchions and pens and my high heels, ready to take on the rioters who were banging on the doors behind us. Climbing over chairs and under rails not sure where the rioters were.
I‚Äôll never forget waiting for the elevator door to open, sure we were going to see a machine gun, and for it all to be over.
I‚Äôll never forget the buzzing of the escape hoods. The fear when I couldn‚Äôt open the packaging. The sound of the doors closing and being locked.
January 6 was my fourth day in office. I, like many of my colleagues, was watching the certification of the election results from the House Gallery because of COVID protocols.

I still didn‚Äôt know how to get around the Capitol building and I‚Äôd never even been in the Gallery before, which I would come to learn was totally cut off from the rest of the Chamber ‚Äì and from the emergency exits.

I just walked into the @January6thCmte hearing. I'm sitting with the same colleagues I was trapped with in the House Gallery on January 6.

We deserve to know the truth about what happened that day, who was involved, and how we are going to hold them accountable. üßµ...

Russia has a track record of not mitigating civilian harm in Syria and elsewhere and has been accused in the past of targeting civilians. We're seeing the same story in Ukraine.

It‚Äôs understandable to want to do more. But we must understand what is at stake. The risks of two nuclear powers going to war are dramatically increased by a no-fly zone. This is unimaginable, and would risk many more civilian casualties than a no-fly zone would save.
And if Russia retaliated, as they certainly would, our Article 5 obligation would be triggered ‚Äì and the U.S. would be at war with Russia.
This would mean the U.S. declaring war on Russia. The same goes for if a NATO ally were to enforce the no-fly zone. They too might have to shoot down Russian jets.

The U.S. & NATO are united in our support for Ukraine. It's the right thing to do in the face of Russian aggression ‚Äîbut we need to be smart about how we do that.

A no-fly zone seems simple, even the bare minimum to save lives. But let‚Äôs talk through what this actually means. üßµ

A no-fly zone is enforced, not declared. It requires our fighter jets to go directly against Russian fighter jets, to get them to stay out of a certain airspace. If the U.S. were to do this, our fighter jets would potentially have to shoot down Russian jets.

In #CA53, more than 148,000 kids live in households that will receive the Child Tax Credit ‚Äî that‚Äôs 84% of all the kids in our district. 

44,600 households will receive an average benefit of $2,900. That‚Äôs 12,400 kids who will no longer experience poverty.

The long-term implications for the CTC are enormous. In April, I sent a letter to @POTUS encouraging him to support making the tax credit permanent ‚Äî so that we can keep up this progress and support the 5 million kids who will still experience poverty. https://t.co/jLg0Q5Pl2D https://t.co/EXLCfytO6R
Nationwide, the expanded Child Tax Credit is projected to cut childhood poverty in half, lifting 5 million American children out of poverty.

The #ChildTaxCredit means a tax cut for working families all across the country. As Jeffrey Hoehn of @CLNkids said, ‚ÄúSingle mothers know where every penny goes. They just don‚Äôt have enough pennies to go around.‚Äù That goes for so many working parents in #CA53.

We say ‚Äúexpanded and improved‚Äù because we increased the CTC from $2,000 up to $3,000 per kid per year ‚Äî and up to $3,600 per kid under 6. And we also made sure more lower-income families are eligible.

If you filed your 2020 taxes, you don‚Äôt have to do anything to apply. And for the families that didn‚Äôt file a 2020 tax return, the IRS created a non-filer tool that will automatically determine your eligibility and get you set up to receive the payments. https://t.co/if10YpNpFm
Now, starting next month, families across the country will start receiving monthly payments directly into their bank accounts or mailboxes ‚Äî up to $300 per child per month.

As many of you know, one of my top priorities in Congress is ending childhood poverty. Before I was elected, I founded a non-profit coalition dedicating to ending the experience of child poverty in San Diego County.

In San Diego, for all the Fortune 500 companies and mansions on the beach, we also had more than 40% of kids living in households experiencing poverty. That‚Äôs unacceptable. And that was before the pandemic.
